paragraphs.text:
%md 
## Setup

 1. First configure the Interpreters.
 2. Add the MongoDB Spark Connector to the Spark Interpreter `org.mongodb.spark:mongo-spark-connector_2.11:2.0.0`
 3. Profit!

  2. Add the MongoDB Spark Connector to the Spark Interpreter org.mongodb.spark:mongo-spark-connector_2.11:2.0.0
  3. Profit!

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Using MongoDB And Spark to calculate the shortest route between Europes largest cities.

Congratulations, you've won the EuroMillions lottery! To celebrate you want to travel to Europes largest 50 cities! The *nouveau riche* only have one way to travel; in style by personal helicopter! However, remembering your humble beginnings you want to ensure your carbon footprint is kept to a minimum. So you want to travel the **shortest route possible between cities**.

It’s a logistical nightmare. Working out the shortest round trip between a fixed number of points is a well-studied and notoriously difficult mathematical problem, usually called the Travelling Salesman Problem, or TSP.

The difficulty arises from the number of possible tours. With, say, 50 places to visit, there are 49 x 48 x 47 x … x 3 x 2 x 1 ways to travel between them. This number is 63 digits long:

**608,281,864,034,267,560,872,252,163,321,295,376,887,552,831,379,210,240,000,000,000**

It’s absurdly big. Humungous! So, just say we wanted to find the shortest route between the 50 cities, how would might we do it?

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Configuring the MongoDB Spark Connector

The City data is stored in the `sparkDemo` database in the `tsp` collection.  Setup Spark and create a `ReadConfig` to read from that collection:

```scala
import com.mongodb.spark._
import com.mongodb.spark.config._

val readConfig = ReadConfig(Map("uri" -> "mongodb://mongodb:27017/sparkDemo.tsp"))

import org.apache.spark.sql.SparkSession
val spark = SparkSession.builder().getOrCreate()
```

## Solving the shortest route

Here we'll use a **Genetic Algorithm** approach. At a basic level, the genetic algorthim works by generating random routes between cities, finding the best ones and then recombining and mutating these best ones to find even better ones. This is done in over a number of generations.

The first step is to define some basic data holding classes:

```scala
case class City(name: String, country: String, lat: Double, lon: Double)
```
The `City` class also has a companion object with some basic helper functions to calculate the straight line distance between cities. Along side the `City` we need to store a route through all the cities. The `Tour` class contains the path and a calculated distance:

```scala
case class Tour(cities: Seq[City], path: Seq[Int], distance: Double)
```

Now the data holders are defined, we can look at how to calculate the shortest route through all the cities.

## Finding a Solution

To find the best path, I've created a `Solver` class. This class does all the work in finding the best route through the cities. Its a simple
map reduce.


### Map

The `evolve` method does the real work by looping through the generations for each group of tours and returns the next generation of tours ordered by distance (shortest first).

```scala
def evolve(tours: Seq[Tour], maxGenerations: Int, maxSimilarity: Double, elitism: Double,  mutationRate: Double): Seq[Tour] = {

    var currGeneration = tours
    var bestGeneration = currGeneration
    var (i, noImprovement) = (1, 0)
    
    // Go through each generation until all done or two generations in a row fail to improve the path
    while (i < maxGenerations && noImprovement < 2) {
    
      // Save the best of the last generation
      val elites = currGeneration.take(Math.round(elitism * currGeneration.size).toInt)
      
      // Create new children and mutate the gene pool
      val children = currGeneration.takeRight(currGeneration.size - elites.size)
                        .map(tour => cross(tour, currGeneration, maxSimilarity))
                        .map(t =>if (mutationRate == 1.0 || RANDOM.nextDouble() < mutationRate) mutate(t) else t)
    
      
      currGeneration = (elites ++ children).sortBy(_.distance)
      
      if (currGeneration.head.distance < bestGeneration.head.distance) {
        bestGeneration = currGeneration
      } else {
        noImprovement += 1
      }
      i += 1
    }
    
    // Make the tour circular
    bestGeneration.map(t => Tour(t.cities, t.path :+ t.path.head))
}

```

#### Crossover explained

To create the next generation we  use a greedy crossover algorithm:

First randomly select a start city then:
 
1. Inspect the parents neighbouring cities
  (If one of the parents neighbouring cities is already in the child route pick a random unpicked city).
2. Pick the nearest city
3. Add to child route
4. Goto 1 until no cities left

In the example below 3 is randomly choosen and the nearest neighbour is 6:

![GreedyCrossOver](/assets/images/greedyCrossOver.png "Greedy crossover image") 

This quickly optimizes the next generation.

#### Mutation explained

We also enhance mutation algorithm by using a 2opt algorithm. The main idea behind it is to take a route that crosses over itself and reorder it so that it does not.

![Mutation](/assets/images/mutation.png "Mutation image") 


### Reduce

The `fittest` method is a simple reduction and only selects the tour smallest path.

```scala
def fittest(a: Tour, b: Tour): Tour = Seq(a, b).sortBy(_.distance).head
```

## Finding the shortest route

First we load the data from MongoDB into a `Dataset[City]`.
```scala
// Load the data from MongoDB
val cities =  spark.read.options(readConfig.asOptions).format("com.mongodb.spark.sql").load().as[City].limit(NUMBER_OF_CITIES_TO_VISIT).collect().toSeq
```

Then in Spark create `n` partitions containing a `Seq[Tour]` and each tour should be different containing a random path through the cities. Then the tours are evolved over a number of generations and flattened. Finally, the reduce method produces a single winner with the shortest route.

```scala
val route = sc.parallelize((1 to PARTITIONS).map(i => (1 to POPULATION_SIZE).map( i => Tour(cities))), PARTITIONS)
  .flatMap(tour => Solver.evolve(tour, MAX_GENERATION, MAX_SIMILARITY, ELITISM, MUTATION_RATE))
  .reduce((a: Tour, b: Tour) => Solver.fittest(a, b))
```

## Results

Configuring the MongoDB Spark Connector

The City data is stored in the sparkDemo database in the tsp collection. Setup Spark and create a ReadConfig to read from that collection:

import com.mongodb.spark._
import com.mongodb.spark.config._

val readConfig = ReadConfig(Map("uri" -> "mongodb://mongodb:27017/sparkDemo.tsp"))

import org.apache.spark.sql.SparkSession
val spark = SparkSession.builder().getOrCreate()

Solving the shortest route

Here we'll use a Genetic Algorithm approach. At a basic level, the genetic algorthim works by generating random routes between cities, finding the best ones and then recombining and mutating these best ones to find even better ones. This is done in over a number of generations.

The first step is to define some basic data holding classes:

case class City(name: String, country: String, lat: Double, lon: Double)

The City class also has a companion object with some basic helper functions to calculate the straight line distance between cities. Along side the City we need to store a route through all the cities. The Tour class contains the path and a calculated distance:

case class Tour(cities: Seq[City], path: Seq[Int], distance: Double)

Now the data holders are defined, we can look at how to calculate the shortest route through all the cities.

Finding a Solution

To find the best path, I've created a Solver class. This class does all the work in finding the best route through the cities. Its a simple
map reduce.

Map

The evolve method does the real work by looping through the generations for each group of tours and returns the next generation of tours ordered by distance (shortest first).

def evolve(tours: Seq[Tour], maxGenerations: Int, maxSimilarity: Double, elitism: Double,  mutationRate: Double): Seq[Tour] = {

    var currGeneration = tours
    var bestGeneration = currGeneration
    var (i, noImprovement) = (1, 0)

    // Go through each generation until all done or two generations in a row fail to improve the path
    while (i < maxGenerations && noImprovement < 2) {

      // Save the best of the last generation
      val elites = currGeneration.take(Math.round(elitism * currGeneration.size).toInt)

      // Create new children and mutate the gene pool
      val children = currGeneration.takeRight(currGeneration.size - elites.size)
                        .map(tour => cross(tour, currGeneration, maxSimilarity))
                        .map(t =>if (mutationRate == 1.0 || RANDOM.nextDouble() < mutationRate) mutate(t) else t)


      currGeneration = (elites ++ children).sortBy(_.distance)

      if (currGeneration.head.distance < bestGeneration.head.distance) {
        bestGeneration = currGeneration
      } else {
        noImprovement += 1
      }
      i += 1
    }

    // Make the tour circular
    bestGeneration.map(t => Tour(t.cities, t.path :+ t.path.head))
}

Crossover explained

To create the next generation we use a greedy crossover algorithm:

First randomly select a start city then:

  1. Inspect the parents neighbouring cities
    (If one of the parents neighbouring cities is already in the child route pick a random unpicked city).
  2. Pick the nearest city
  3. Add to child route
  4. Goto 1 until no cities left

In the example below 3 is randomly choosen and the nearest neighbour is 6:

This quickly optimizes the next generation.

Mutation explained

We also enhance mutation algorithm by using a 2opt algorithm. The main idea behind it is to take a route that crosses over itself and reorder it so that it does not.

Reduce

The fittest method is a simple reduction and only selects the tour smallest path.

def fittest(a: Tour, b: Tour): Tour = Seq(a, b).sortBy(_.distance).head

Finding the shortest route

First we load the data from MongoDB into a Dataset[City].

// Load the data from MongoDB
val cities =  spark.read.options(readConfig.asOptions).format("com.mongodb.spark.sql").load().as[City].limit(NUMBER_OF_CITIES_TO_VISIT).collect().toSeq

Then in Spark create n partitions containing a Seq[Tour] and each tour should be different containing a random path through the cities. Then the tours are evolved over a number of generations and flattened. Finally, the reduce method produces a single winner with the shortest route.

val route = sc.parallelize((1 to PARTITIONS).map(i => (1 to POPULATION_SIZE).map( i => Tour(cities))), PARTITIONS)
  .flatMap(tour => Solver.evolve(tour, MAX_GENERATION, MAX_SIMILARITY, ELITISM, MUTATION_RATE))
  .reduce((a: Tour, b: Tour) => Solver.fittest(a, b))

paragraphs.text:
val stats = RouteStats(NUMBER_OF_CITIES_TO_VISIT, PARTITIONS, POPULATION_SIZE, MAX_GENERATION, MAX_SIMILARITY, ELITISM, duration.toSeconds, route.distance.toInt)
runs += stats
z.angularBind("mapRoutePoints", route.path.map(route.cities(_)).toArray)
z.angularBind("latestRun", stats)

result.msg: Latest Run took: {{seconds}} Seconds

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Further reading:

  * A shortest-possible walking tour through the pubs of the United Kingdom. [http://www.math.uwaterloo.ca/tsp/pubs/](http://www.math.uwaterloo.ca/tsp/pubs/)
  * Running a Genetic Algorithm on Apache Spark [http://www.niels.nu/blog/2016/spark-of-life-genetic-algorithm.html](http://www.niels.nu/blog/2016/spark-of-life-genetic-algorithm.html)
  * Applying a genetic algorithm to the traveling salesman problem [http://www.theprojectspot.com/tutorial-post/applying-a-genetic-algorithm-to-the-travelling-salesman-problem/5](http://www.theprojectspot.com/tutorial-post/applying-a-genetic-algorithm-to-the-travelling-salesman-problem/5)
  * Genetic Algorithms [http://www.obitko.com/tutorials/genetic-algorithms/index.php](http://www.obitko.com/tutorials/genetic-algorithms/index.php)
  * Developing Improved Greedy Crossover to Solve Symmetric Traveling Salesman Problem [https://arxiv.org/pdf/1209.5339.pdf](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1209.5339.pdf)
  * Parallel Genetic Algorithm to Solve Traveling Salesman Problem on MapReduce Framework: [https://arxiv.org/pdf/1401.6267.pdf]([https://arxiv.org/pdf/1401.6267.pdf)
  * Comparison of TSP Algorithms [http://bardzo.be/4sem/NAI/rozne/Comparison%20of%20TSP%20Algorithms/Comparison%20of%20TSP%20Algorithms.PDF](http://bardzo.be/4sem/NAI/rozne/Comparison%20of%20TSP%20Algorithms/Comparison%20of%20TSP%20Algorithms.PDF)
